awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Building Knowledge on Genotyping Seagrasses to Assess Competitive Interactions under Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
Biodiversity affects the proper functioning of ecosystems, their resistance to environmental changes, and their ability to recover after disturbance. One component of biodiversity, the diversity of genes within populations, is receiving more attention following recient technological advances enabling researchers to measure and map genetic diversity in nature. Evidence has shown that this genetic diversity can be as important in maintaining a healthy ecosystem as the number of different species interacting in an area. This work will study how genetic diversity of an important widespread seagrass species affects its competition with seasonally-abundant algae under current and future expected environmental temperature changes. Because seagrass beds are important to maintain coastal water quality, control erosion, and as nursery grounds for commercially important species, this research is relevant to the ecology, economics and food security of coastal zones. The funding will establish an active collaboration between the researcher and his graduate student from the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI, a HBCU) and researchers at the University of California at Davis; and will take advantage of the world-class Climate Change Research Facility at Bodega Marine Laboratory. Additionally, this fellowship will facilitate the development of techniques to assess genetic diversity of Caribbean seagrasses, which are facing multiple environmental threats including possible displacement by a fast-spreading introduced seagrass originally form the Red Sea an Indian Ocean. These techniques will be leveraged to develop future proposals and provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at UVI.

Technical Description
Recent work has highlighted that intraspecific genetic diversity may be as important as species diversity in mediating ecosystem function, resistance to disturbance and resilience. Under the context of climate change, genetic diversity has also received attention for determining adaptive potential of species to global temperature increases. However, temperature also has a strong effect on species interactions. To date, the combined effects of genotype and temperature on interaction strength remain unknown. This work will evaluate the influence of plant genotype in determining the outcome of competition between the seagrass Zostera marina, an important ecosystem engineer, and the seasonally-abundant green alga Ulva lactuca. By conducting experiments at the Climate Change Research Facility of Bodega Marine Laboratory (BML) housed at the University of California at Davis, this research will assess the outcome of competitive interactions between Z. marina known genotypes and U. lactuca, under current and future temperatures predicted by global warming models. The fellowship will provide a transformative opportunity for the PI and a graduate student from the University of the Virgin Islands (a HBCU) by establishing a synergistic collaboration with experts at UC Davis and BML. In particular, the seagrass genotyping techniques developed by collaborators at UC Davis will be adapted to the study of Caribbean species, which are currently declining as a result of multiple environmental stressors including potential displacement by the introduced seagrass Halophila stipulacea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the expected, and already observed, effects of climate change is an increase in the frequency and intensity of heat waves. While a number of studies have quantified species-specific effects of warmer waters on the physiology and biology of marine plants and animals, less is known about how warming events affect species interactions. Much less is known about how these effects are modulated by the genetic makeup of the species involved, an important component to understand how biodiversity and community resilience are related. On the west coast of the United States, where pervasive heat waves have been well documented, the seagrass Zostera marina is a key foundational species on soft bottom communities, serving and nursery and feeding grounds for a multitude of commercially important species. During the summer months, green algae (several species of Ulva) compete with seagrass and can depress its biomass locally. Work at the University of California at Davis has established clonal lines of this seagrass, providing a unique opportunity to quantify interactions among temperature and seagrass genotype in the face of competition. Multifactorial experiments using ten different seagrass genotypes and field-collected algae were cultured in these experiments for three weeks, following a period of acclimation. Seagrass genotypes were selected to represent a gradient of heat resistant to heat sensitive plants. Results showed complex and nuanced interactions in this system. While green algae were not affected by simulated heat waves, temperature actually increased seagrass growth but had no effect on plant survivorship. As expected temperature effects on the seagrass were significantly affected by genotype. Interestingly, genotype interacted with competition to modulate seagrass growth; some genotypes grew less in the presence of competing algae but not others, and the magnitude of such effects varied with the temperature of the water, although not uniformly among all seagrass clones. Experiments testing the palatability of the seagrass grown under the different combinations using an abundant isopod herbivore did not find any differences, although replication was constrained.

For the second year, the idea of intraspecific variation in seagrass traits was applied to studies of the invasive seagrass Halophila stipulacea. This seagrass, originally from the Red Sea and Indian Ocean, was first observed in the Caribbean in 2002 and arrived in the US Virgin Islands in 2012. At present it is the dominant seagrass in many coastal areas across 24 countries. The effects of population origin and depth were tested in St. Thomas, using a series of feeding choice experiments with three Caribbean herbivores, two crab and one urchin species. Three depths and four sites were selected and all possible pairwise iterations were experimentally assessed, as abundance of the seagrass permitted. A total of 45 comparisons among sites and 30 comparisons across depths were conducted. Additionally, herbivory was quantified across four sites and three depths by counting feeding scars on field-collected plants. Palatability of the seagrass was relatively uniform, with only 4 comparisons among depths and 5 comparisons between sites showing any indication of differences in palatability. For that small subset, the deeper populations of one of the four sites (Lindbergh Bay) tended to be more palatable. Interestingly, this slight different in palatability did not correlate with herbivore damage, with a different site (Frenchman Bay) showing more grazing scars on leaves across depths.

                This grant also facilitated a collaboration with a PhD student from the University of California, Los Angeles, assessing competition between the invasive seagrass and native species. Common garden experiments in the Caribbean and Mediterranean (where H. stipulacea invaded > 100 years ago) shwed that, surprisingly, the invasive grew better when native species were present than when growing by itself, showing that an unexplored mechanism of facilitation has enhanced the success of this invader.

                The grant supported the thesis of one M.S. student at the University of the Virgin Islands (graduated in 2021), provided data for the thesis projects of two additional M. S. students working on seagrass ecology, and allowed the collaboration highlighted above. All students engaged were members of underrepresented groups in STEM. Additionally, teaching modules for two courses (Ecology and Aquatic Plant Biology) were developed. Results were also presented at the Benthic Ecology Meeting, two radio interviews, and on the VI-EPSCoR newsletter and website.
